Dear Ms. Nye:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
4/27/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly
Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services
worker that has children placed in the home.
One of one special evaluation did not have documentation that a copy of the report
was provided to the foster care worker.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed
corrective action plan, all social service workers who
have children placed in the home shall be notified there
is a corrective action plan (CAP) and what is required of
the foster parent in that plan.
One of one special evaluations did not have documentation the foster care worker
was informed of the CAP.
2

CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement
to a youth before placement in independent living.
One of one IL file did not have documentation the program statement was provided
to the youth.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living
with a copy of the agency’s policies and procedures
required by this rule.
One of one IL file did not have documentation the youth was provided with the
agencies policies & procedures.
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service
worker and the youth in independent living at least once
each month at a youth’s place of residence.
(c) Provide the youth with a telephone number to
contact the agency on a 24-hour, 7-days-a-week basis.
(a) One of one IL files did not have monthly budgets on file for February or
March 2023.
(c) One of one IL files did not have documentation the youth was provided with a
24/7 emergency phone number to reach the agency.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living contract
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The contract shall
be reviewed and updated at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
3

One of one IL files did not have an IL contract signed by the youth and worker when
the case was accepted.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Borrowed Beds- the agency can use one single document to record
"endorsement" of reports as required by the rule. The document should
detail which report was reviewed, the date, and the person that reviewed
it.
• Special Evaluations- clarification was provided that a special evaluation
conclusion is when the agency provides the foster parent with a verbal
summary of findings. The written report is then due within 10 days from
the conclusion.
• Independent Living- a reminder was provided that when an IL case moves
from one DHHS office to another, the initial IL documentation from the rule
must be completed by the receiving office. This includes policy/procedure
review, program statement, IL contract, monthly budget, 30-day modified
service plan, etc.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Not requested.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. One
CAP was approved on 3/24/22 as a result of the 3/4/22 renewal evaluation. The
agency reported successful implementation of their CAP during this past year.
Staff reported the CAP as something that is frequently discussed and reviewed
with everyone. During this review it was determined the agency significantly
decreased the number of violations found. The few citations noted in this
evaluation were not repeat violations and the agency has identified the issue that
caused the violation. Overall, the agency has demonstrated successful CAP
implementation and compliance improvement.
Chief Administrator Assessment
4

The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and discussed with the
agency. The CAA identified several actions that were taken to implement the CAP
from the 2022 renewal review. Overall, the agency reported the steps have been
successful. Staffing has been stable, which has also assisted in maintaining
compliance. The CAA reported one struggle over this past year with finding and
maintaining placements for children. Several disrupted placements have occurred
in the past year. Some changes occurred for positive reasons such as sibling
reunification or adoption. However, the majority of placement changes were due to
foster parent request. The agency identified the likely cause is related to having
limited placement options when the child first came into care. Meaning the initial
placement may not be the best fit, resulting in placement change later.
Financial Overview
No financial concerns were noted.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Two staff interviews were completed. Both staff reported being satisfied with their
supervisor, co-workers, and the agency overall. One employee noted they
specifically came to this office to work with their now supervisor. The employee
stated the supervisor is competent, confident, knowledgeable, helpful and
compassionate, which makes a tremendous difference in employee satisfaction. It
was noted there was some morale issues during the past two years, which the
staff believe the Chief Administrator did an excellent job of addressing head on.
The CA scheduled meetings with everyone to problem solve and a staff advocacy
team was developed to give staff an avenue to address any concerns.
Neither of the staff reported any ongoing concerns or areas that need
improvement.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is located in an office building in the city of Hillsdale. The building is
sufficient for file storage, staff activities, and has visitation space for families. No
concerns were found.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
5

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
